Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis program of the Division of Chemistry supports the research of Professor Corey Stephenson. Professor Stephenson is a faculty member at the University of Michigan. The goal of the project is to develop sustainable photocatalytic chemical methods for biomass degradation and repurposing. The total amount of biomass currently produced by the forestry and agricultural industries is estimated to be sufficient to replace petroleum as a carbon feedstock for fine chemicals. The Stephenson group is developing methods to degrade and convert lignin, the second most abundant biopolymer in the world, to valuable commodity chemicals. Lignin's high aromatic content is converted into useful feedstocks and complementing the aliphatic chemicals that can be derived from cellulose. This research focus is an integral component of Professor Stephenson's educational plans as a training opportunity for students in his laboratory. In addition, it provides hands-on experimental modules integrated into a series of outreach elements designed to engage high school students in the exciting opportunities in green chemistry and molecular sciences. Graduate and undergraduate trainees in the Stephenson group are exposed to a broad range of interdisciplinary topics, such as catalysis, photochemistry, renewable energy and flow chemistry.


The focus is on using electron transfer-initiated transformations to promote chemoselective C-O and C-C bond cleavage reactions of lignin chemical linkages, processes for sustainable chemistry that are situated at the intersection of organometallic chemistry, photochemistry and materials science. These operationally simple, catalytic methods obviate the need for specialized photochemistry equipment, utilizing inexpensive and energy efficient LEDs for irradiation. The challenges of lignin degradation are addressed using a combination of oxidative and reductive visible light-mediated radical chemistry. The proposal consists of three specific aims: 1) development of new catalytic oxidation methods employing both photoredox catalysis and electron shuttling agents; 2) development of novel visible light-mediated reductive C-O and C-C cleavage methods; 3) implementation of the strategies developed in aims 1 and 2 toward the degradation of commercial lignin in continuous flow. The objectives advance the broader concept of sustainable chemistry without compromising reaction efficiency and chemoselectivity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. This project integrates recent advances in lignin depolymerization with principles of photo-redox catalysis and electrocatalysis to enable efficient and environmentally friendly methods for the depolymerization and functionalization of the highly abundant biopolymer, lignin. Natural polymer lignin is a competitive candidate as a sustainable energy source but highly resistant to degradation. In the past five years, we have disclosed a two-step lignin degradation method in a sequence of oxidation and reduction. Using this general template, we have selectively converted native pine lignin and lignin models into useful products including aromatic ketones, phenols etc. Furthermore, we have developed fundamental knowledge required to depolymerize lignin. For example, a detailed mechanistic study on hydrogen atom transfer mediator catalyzed oxidation provides a good map for the development of similar type of catalysts and reactions. These results suggest that technical advances towards lignin degradation are well underway.

As measured by productivity, the impact of this funding can be seen in the publications and presentations that have arisen during the granting period to disseminate the results to the broader community.

6 peer-reviewed publications with nearly 500 total citations

>30 presentations and posters given by undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows at local, regional and national meetings

Training opportunities for >10 undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows have been facilitated by this research funding

Broader Impacts. Modern day society is intimately tied to its energy usage with an ever-increasing demand that has, to date, mostly been met by the processing and consumption of fossil fuels. Alongside this increased demand for energy is the heightened awareness of the importance of technologies that harness renewable sources for energy and chemicals. Lignin is one of the potential renewable energy sources for production of aromatics. The study towards lignin degradation provides potential solutions to fight against climate change and build a sustainable chemical production process. Furthermore, the utility of free radicals for chemical production has not been fully realized as a consequence of the means by which they are traditionally generated, and the environmental impact of the byproducts of their formation. Visible light photocatalysis and electrocatalysis have helped to reinvigorate research into mild and environmentally benign approaches to access these versatile species.

The University of Michigan is a state university dedicated to educating, ground-breaking scientific research, and outreach at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. Importantly, Michigan is an institution that promotes diversity in all education areas. As part of this NSF award, we have undertaken two major efforts in this regard.

Michigan Math and Science Scholars Program (MMSS). We have organized and supervised the Michigan Math Science Scholars course on Green Chemistry, Catalysis and Solar Energy Conversion. These courses last for two weeks (two sessions each summer with ~30 students) and are aimed at introducing a diverse set of high school students to advanced concepts in catalysis with an emphasis on sustainable chemistry. This educational program requires each of the graduate students in the group to design an experiment adhering to the course's goal of Green Chemistry, Catalysis, and Solar Energy; preparing a written step-by-step laboratory procedure for the students; supervising and teaching the students for a day-long session; and finally to encourage students to actively participate in hands-on activities and field-trips to Cayman Chemical, Dow Chemical, and a local botanical garden where the students learned about chemicals in nature. The ultimate goal for this program is to encourage high school students of various backgrounds to become excited about the STEM fields. In the summer of 2020, we adapted this course to a month-long virtual experience due to the COVID pandemic.

Females Excelling in More in Math, Engineering and the Sciences (FEMMES). The FEMMES program offers the opportunity for research groups at the university, across multiple scientific disciplines, to design and lead activities that educate local elementary school-level girls about each group's respective research fields.  Every semester, graduate students in our group organize a day of fun, chemistry-focused demonstrations and activities (e.g. making liquid nitrogen ice cream) for the goal of introducing elementary school-level girls to basic chemistry concepts in an exciting, hands-on manner.  Through our participation in the FEMMES program, we hope to actively reach out to young girls in the community to help them foster an interest in chemistry, as well as develop greater knowledge and confidence in learning about STEM fields.
